THE BRlGANn LEADER AND HIS WIFI


By 1frs. Htmans.
Dark chiefiain of the heath and height,
Wild feaster on the hills BY night!
Seeat thou the stormy sunsets glow,
Flung back by glancing spears below
Now for one strife of stern despair
Z he foe hath track d thee 10 thy lair.
Thou against whem the voice Of blood,
Hath risen from rock and lonely wood,
And iii whose dreams moan should be,
Not of the water, nor the tree;
Haply thine own last hour is nigh,
Yet shalt thou mt forsaken die.
There's one that pale beside thee stands.
More true than all thy mountain bands
She will not shrink in doubt ard dread,
Wien the balls whistle round thy head;
Nor leave thee, though thy closing eye,
No longer may to hers reply.
OH many soft and quiet grace
Hath faded from her soul and face;
And many thought, the fitting guest
Of woman's meek religious breast,
Hath perisiI'd, in her wanderings wides
Through the deep forests, by thy side.
Yet mournfnlly surviving all,
A flower upon ruins wall,
A friendless thing, whose lot is cast,
OF lovely ones to be the last;
Sad, but unchanged through good and i'll,
Thine is her lone devotion still.
And, oh not wholly lost the heart.
Where that undying love hath part;
Not worthless all, though far and long
From home estranged, and guided wrong
Yet. may its depths by Heav'n be stirr'd.
Its prayer for thee be pour'd and heard
Tuesday and Friday, by albert & Henry

Mr. Editor--Ihe late accident which happened
to the chain bridge at Ne@buryport, seems some-
what mysterious, after all the solutions which have
been offered. The increased tension of the chains
in consequence of the cold, has been assigDed--but
the operation Of this, would naturally suppose
would simply have been to raise the bridge The
weight upon the bridge at the time Of The accident
would hardly appear TO be of much importance
AS to the effect of ros, in weakening the tenancy
of the chains, which has been particularly mention
ed, am not sufficiently acquainted 20 judge. 1t
would seem to be the most probable reason OF the
three. But upon seeing the account l was imme@
dia,ely reminded of curious TACT related 10 me
few years since by an eminent Physician as to the
power oflong continued tremor in changing the il.
terpal structure and weakening The natural cohes-
ion of iron. He obse rived, that distinguished
philosophca and pi actical mtchanician had Bi0rm-
ed him he had asce tanned by experiment, that iron
subjected for long time TO a constant lar became
coarse in its grain. so that cor pa susely slight
blow would be sufficient to break L. He sdded,
that he had found this to be true IN repeaed insen-
ces-and the iron when broken exhibited at The
frac,nre the appearance Of facets granuies mach
larger than Ordinary


Il there be no mistake as to this fact, we hard
y be surprised that chains which have been precise
" in the kind of motion described ful twenty
years. should during SO long space have become
materially affected By it. The suggestion may be





Newbury was one Of the very earliest experiments
Of the kind. II was boased in England OF one e
rected in that country. that il was the First which
had ever been built But it was subsequent TO that
., Newburyport. II. -4rgas.

NEWBURYPORT BRIDGE.

lhe following dUeCdOle 1S quOteu from LHe new
Philadelphia Quarterly.


When the British army held possession of Phila-
Lelphia, Gen. Howe's headquarters were in Sec
nnd street the fourth door below Spruce, in house
which was before occupied by Gen. Cadwallader.
Directly opposite, resided William and Lydia Dar-
rah members of the society of Friends A supe-
rior officer Of the British Army, believed to be the
adiutant general fixed upon of their chambers
back room, for private conference; and two Of
them frequently met there. with fire and candles in
close consultation. About the Cd of December, the
adiutant general told Lsda that they would be in
tho room at O'Clock, and remain late; and that
they wished the family to retire early to beds add
ing that when they were going away they would
call her to let them out and extnguish their fire
and candles. She accordingly sent all the family
to bed but as the officer had been particular.
her curiosity was excited. She took off her shoes,
and put her ear to the KEY hole Of the conclave and
overheard an order read for all the British troops
ia march out late in the evening of the fourth, and
attack General Washington's army, then encamp-
ed at White Marsh. On hearing this she returned
to her chamber. and laid down. Soon after, the
officers knocked at the door. but she rose only at
the third summons, having fcigned herself asleep


Her mind was so much agitated. that from this mo-
ment she could neither eat nor sleep supposinglt
to be in her power to save the lives OF thousands OF
her fellow -countrymen; but not knowing how she





not daring to confde it to her husband. The time
left. however. was shcrt. She quickly determined
to make her way. as soon as possible, to the Amer-
can outposts She informed her family, that, as she
was N want of -four, she would go to Frankford for
some her husband insisted that she should take
the servant maid with her. but to his surprise she
positively refused She got access to Gen. Howe.
and solicited, what he readily granted, pass
through the British troops on the lines. Leaving
her baa at the mill, she fastened towards the Anne
can lines and encountered on her way an Amer-
can lieutenant colonel (Craig) of the light horse,
who, with some of his men. was on the lookout tor
inflammation. He knew her, and inquired where
she was going She answered, in quest OF her son,
an officer in the American army, and prayed the
colonel to aliaht and walk with her tie did SO,
ordering his troops to keep in sight To him she
disclosed her secret, after having obtained from
him solemn promise never to betray her ndividu-
alIy as her life might be at stake with the British


He conducted her to house near at hand, direct
ed something for her to eat, and hastened to head
quarters when he brought Gen. Washington ac'
auaintel with what he had heard. washington
! made, of course, all preparation Tor nafning the
meditated surprise. Lydia returned nome witf


her -four; sat up alone to watch the movemehL .
the British troops heard their footsteps but wher
they returned in few days after, did not dare tt
ask question: though solcitous to learn the event
! The next evening the Adjutant General came IN
). and requested her to walk up to his room as ht


wished to put some questions. She followed hin
in terror; and when he locked the door and begget


her, with an air of mystery, to be seated, she wa
i, sure that she was either suspected or had been be
i trayed. lie inquired earnestly whether any OF he


family were up the last night he and the other ON
IL cor met she told him that they all retired at eIgh


o'clock. He observed, g know you were asleep
far Knocked at your chamber door three times be
IS tore you heard am entirely at loss to INA


T;n,enIed attack unless the walls of the house cou


sneak. When we arrived near White Marsh, W


Tnnnd all their cannon mounted, and the troops pre-


pared to receive US, and we have marched bac
e like parcel of fools"

CONDITIONS OF THE WATCHMAN

A horse ought to eat at least from sixteen to
twenty quarts of oats per day, otherwise he will
not and cannot perform a long journey. Clean
fresh hay and little water, should be given Of
ten as you stop.


Never trust to ostlers when you are on jour
ney. 1t is essentially necessary that YOU person.
ally see to the cleaning, waterng feeding. aud lit
terng Of your horse, otherwise you will in all pro-
liability soon be under the necessity of hiring or
purchasing another or abandoning your journey.


Should your horse lose his appetite, give him an
ounce of nitre in bran-mash once or twice. This,
with a little rest, will soon recover him.


Deane's New. England Farmer says, To fit
horse for journey, he should not be suffered to
grow too fat and gross. He should be kept in the
Stable rather than in the pasture. and fed mostly
with provender; but rather sparingy if inclined
to be fat. He should have exercise daily to harden
his flesh and keep him in the habit Of travelling.
He should be shod some days before he begins
Journey, that the shoes may be well settled to his
feet, and the nails little rusted at the points, that
they hold the faster. And the pads Of the saddle
should be WE'LL fitted to his back as to fill the
hoows, and bear equally on every part. And
while he is on journey he should be stabbed eve
ry night. 1t is very destructive To expose horses
to the dampness and cold Of the night after severe
exercise

From the Near England Farmer.
MANAGEMENT OF HORSES ON JOUR-
-.NEY.

Pulse of Horse.-In the management Of sick
horses great advantage may be derived from attend
ing to the state of the pulse, we are thereby en-
abIed to Judge Of the degree Of violence of the
disease, and the probability there may be Of reco.
very. We are in some measure also assisted by it
IN ascertaining the nature Of the complaint. and
the application Of remedies.


In healthy horse the pulsations are about Sc or
40 in minute, and may be felt very distinctly ei-
ther on the left side, or in artery which passes
over the lower jaw bone in short, pulsation may
be felt in every superficial artery.


When horse appears rather dull, and does not
feed properly, it is advisable to examine the pulse,
and if he be found exceed the standard Of health
immediate recourse should be had to bleehing.-
By this timely interference many dangerous com
plants may be prevented. When the pulse rises
to 80 in minute, there is reason to be apprehen-
sive Of danger and when it exceeds 100 the dis
ease frequently terminates in death.


White's Treatise on Veterinary Medicine.

THE BRIGANn LEADER AND HIS WIFE
full articles.article:
THE BRlGANn LEADER AND HIS WIFI


By 1frs. Htmans.
Dark chiefiain of the heath and height,
Wild feaster on the hills BY night!
Seeat thou the stormy sunsets glow,
Flung back by glancing spears below
Now for one strife of stern despair
Z he foe hath track d thee 10 thy lair.
Thou against whem the voice Of blood,
Hath risen from rock and lonely wood,
And iii whose dreams moan should be,
Not of the water, nor the tree;
Haply thine own last hour is nigh,
Yet shalt thou mt forsaken die.
There's one that pale beside thee stands.
More true than all thy mountain bands
She will not shrink in doubt ard dread,
Wien the balls whistle round thy head;
Nor leave thee, though thy closing eye,
No longer may to hers reply.
OH many soft and quiet grace
Hath faded from her soul and face;
And many thought, the fitting guest
Of woman's meek religious breast,
Hath perisiI'd, in her wanderings wides
Through the deep forests, by thy side.
Yet mournfnlly surviving all,
A flower upon ruins wall,
A friendless thing, whose lot is cast,
OF lovely ones to be the last;
Sad, but unchanged through good and i'll,
Thine is her lone devotion still.
And, oh not wholly lost the heart.
Where that undying love hath part;
Not worthless all, though far and long
From home estranged, and guided wrong
Yet. may its depths by Heav'n be stirr'd.
Its prayer for thee be pour'd and heard

lhe following dUeCdOle 1S quOteu from LHe new
Philadelphia Quarterly.


When the British army held possession of Phila-
Lelphia, Gen. Howe's headquarters were in Sec
nnd street the fourth door below Spruce, in house
which was before occupied by Gen. Cadwallader.
Directly opposite, resided William and Lydia Dar-
rah members of the society of Friends A supe-
rior officer Of the British Army, believed to be the
adiutant general fixed upon of their chambers
back room, for private conference; and two Of
them frequently met there. with fire and candles in
close consultation. About the Cd of December, the
adiutant general told Lsda that they would be in
tho room at O'Clock, and remain late; and that
they wished the family to retire early to beds add
ing that when they were going away they would
call her to let them out and extnguish their fire
and candles. She accordingly sent all the family
to bed but as the officer had been particular.
her curiosity was excited. She took off her shoes,
and put her ear to the KEY hole Of the conclave and
overheard an order read for all the British troops
ia march out late in the evening of the fourth, and
attack General Washington's army, then encamp-
ed at White Marsh. On hearing this she returned
to her chamber. and laid down. Soon after, the
officers knocked at the door. but she rose only at
the third summons, having fcigned herself asleep


Her mind was so much agitated. that from this mo-
ment she could neither eat nor sleep supposinglt
to be in her power to save the lives OF thousands OF
her fellow -countrymen; but not knowing how she





not daring to confde it to her husband. The time
left. however. was shcrt. She quickly determined
to make her way. as soon as possible, to the Amer-
can outposts She informed her family, that, as she
was N want of -four, she would go to Frankford for
some her husband insisted that she should take
the servant maid with her. but to his surprise she
positively refused She got access to Gen. Howe.
and solicited, what he readily granted, pass
through the British troops on the lines. Leaving
her baa at the mill, she fastened towards the Anne
can lines and encountered on her way an Amer-
can lieutenant colonel (Craig) of the light horse,
who, with some of his men. was on the lookout tor
inflammation. He knew her, and inquired where
she was going She answered, in quest OF her son,
an officer in the American army, and prayed the
colonel to aliaht and walk with her tie did SO,
ordering his troops to keep in sight To him she
disclosed her secret, after having obtained from
him solemn promise never to betray her ndividu-
alIy as her life might be at stake with the British


He conducted her to house near at hand, direct
ed something for her to eat, and hastened to head
quarters when he brought Gen. Washington ac'
auaintel with what he had heard. washington
! made, of course, all preparation Tor nafning the
meditated surprise. Lydia returned nome witf


her -four; sat up alone to watch the movemehL .
the British troops heard their footsteps but wher
they returned in few days after, did not dare tt
ask question: though solcitous to learn the event
! The next evening the Adjutant General came IN
). and requested her to walk up to his room as ht


wished to put some questions. She followed hin
in terror; and when he locked the door and begget


her, with an air of mystery, to be seated, she wa
i, sure that she was either suspected or had been be
i trayed. lie inquired earnestly whether any OF he


family were up the last night he and the other ON
IL cor met she told him that they all retired at eIgh


o'clock. He observed, g know you were asleep
far Knocked at your chamber door three times be
IS tore you heard am entirely at loss to INA


T;n,enIed attack unless the walls of the house cou


sneak. When we arrived near White Marsh, W


Tnnnd all their cannon mounted, and the troops pre-


pared to receive US, and we have marched bac
e like parcel of fools"

full articles.headline:
From the Near England Farmer.
MANAGEMENT OF HORSES ON JOUR-
full articles.article:
A horse ought to eat at least from sixteen to
twenty quarts of oats per day, otherwise he will
not and cannot perform a long journey. Clean
fresh hay and little water, should be given Of
ten as you stop.


Never trust to ostlers when you are on jour
ney. 1t is essentially necessary that YOU person.
ally see to the cleaning, waterng feeding. aud lit
terng Of your horse, otherwise you will in all pro-
liability soon be under the necessity of hiring or
purchasing another or abandoning your journey.


Should your horse lose his appetite, give him an
ounce of nitre in bran-mash once or twice. This,
with a little rest, will soon recover him.


Deane's New. England Farmer says, To fit
horse for journey, he should not be suffered to
grow too fat and gross. He should be kept in the
Stable rather than in the pasture. and fed mostly
with provender; but rather sparingy if inclined
to be fat. He should have exercise daily to harden
his flesh and keep him in the habit Of travelling.
He should be shod some days before he begins
Journey, that the shoes may be well settled to his
feet, and the nails little rusted at the points, that
they hold the faster. And the pads Of the saddle
should be WE'LL fitted to his back as to fill the
hoows, and bear equally on every part. And
while he is on journey he should be stabbed eve
ry night. 1t is very destructive To expose horses
to the dampness and cold Of the night after severe
exercise

Pulse of Horse.-In the management Of sick
horses great advantage may be derived from attend
ing to the state of the pulse, we are thereby en-
abIed to Judge Of the degree Of violence of the
disease, and the probability there may be Of reco.
very. We are in some measure also assisted by it
IN ascertaining the nature Of the complaint. and
the application Of remedies.


In healthy horse the pulsations are about Sc or
40 in minute, and may be felt very distinctly ei-
ther on the left side, or in artery which passes
over the lower jaw bone in short, pulsation may
be felt in every superficial artery.


When horse appears rather dull, and does not
feed properly, it is advisable to examine the pulse,
and if he be found exceed the standard Of health
immediate recourse should be had to bleehing.-
By this timely interference many dangerous com
plants may be prevented. When the pulse rises
to 80 in minute, there is reason to be apprehen-
sive Of danger and when it exceeds 100 the dis
ease frequently terminates in death.


White's Treatise on Veterinary Medicine.
